channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: ‘It’s a Massacre’: Taliban Bomb in Ambulance Kills 95 in Kabul
item.media:description: Injured Afghans ran from the scene of the blast, stepping over the dead and the wounded. Kabul’s hospitals were overwhelmed by the number of injured people.
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The New York Times
item.description: At least 158 others were wounded when the bomber drove past two checkpoints and detonated explosives in Kabul, officials said.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and JAWAD SUKHANYAR

item.title: Billionaire Saudi Prince, Alwaleed bin Talal, Is Freed From Detention
item.media:description: Prince Alwaleed bin Talal on Saturday in what was said to be the Ritz-Carlton suite where he was detained in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.
item.description: Saudi Arabia’s most prominent investor, he had been detained in the Ritz-Carlton in the capital after a mass crackdown on corruption.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: In Kenya, and Across Africa, an Unexpected Epidemic: Obesity
item.media:description: Valentine Akinyi talks with her son, Driffal, 11, outside their Nairobi home in the Kibera section of the city.
item.media:credit: Andrew Renneisen for The New York Times
item.description: Growing economies have led to surging obesity rates in sub-Saharan Africa, causing a health crisis that has caught the continent by surprise. One solution? “Eat like grandmum did,” says a doctor.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Czech Republic Re-elects Milos Zeman, Populist Leader and Foe of Migrants
item.media:description: President Milos Zeman in Prague in January. His often-caustic brand of populism has stoked resentment toward Muslim immigrants.
item.description: In rejecting the president’s opponent, the country was poised to continue the same euroskeptic shift as Hungary, Poland and Slovakia.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA

item.title: For Myanmar’s Army, Ethnic Bloodletting Is Key to Power and Riches
item.media:description: A military parade in Myanmar’s capital, Naypyidaw, in March. The army has spent most of the past seven decades warring with its own people.
item.description: Even as it carries out atrocities against Rohingya Muslims, the military has kept up campaigns of violence and resource-grabbing against other minority groups.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Refugees in Indonesia Hoped for Brief Stay. Many May Be Stuck for Life.
item.media:description: Refugees at a low-cost housing compound in Jakarta, Indonesia. The United Nations has begun informing the nearly 14,000 refugees and asylum seekers in the country that it is highly unlikely they will ever be resettled.
item.media:credit: Kemal Jufri for The New York Times
item.description: The nearly 14,000 refugees in Indonesia, many from the Middle East and Africa, were recently told by the United Nations that it is unlikely they will ever be resettled elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Hong Kong Bars Democracy Advocate From Running for Legislature
item.media:description: Agnes Chow campaigning for Hong Kong’s Legislative Council this month. Her party, Demosisto, says the city should hold a referendum to decide its future after 2047, when China’s promises of autonomy and civil liberties expire.
item.description: Agnes Chow, 21, whose party says Hong Kong should decide its future in a referendum, said the ruling showed “that our political rights are handicapped.”
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG

item.title: Every One of the World’s Big Economies Is Now Growing
item.media:description: The reawakening of Europe, combined with growth in the United States, has kept Chinese industry humming to satisfy demand for goods, from auto parts to tools to clothing.
item.description: For the first time since the global economic downturn, there is a wave of expansion that is creating jobs, lifting fortunes and tempering fears of popular discontent.
item.dc:creator: PETER S. GOODMAN

item.title: Finland’s Scene-Stealing First Dog Is Missed During Dull Election
item.media:description: President Sauli Niinisto of Finland, with his wife, Jenni Haukio, and their dog, Lennu.
item.description: Lennu, a much-loved celebrity in Finland, is a Boston terrier with a lolling tongue whose master, the president, is up for re-election. But an illness has apparently kept Lennu off the campaign trail.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD MARTYN-HEMPHILL

item.title: Ambush on Mali Army Camp Leaves 14 Soldiers and 17 Attackers Dead
item.description: Islamic militants stormed the camp in the Timbuktu region, but the military struck back and killed many extremists, an army spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Lifetime in Peru’s Glaciers, Slowly Melting Away
item.media:description: At current melt rates, the Gueshgue glacier and others in the Cordillera Blanca mountain range of Peru could disappear within 50 years, glaciologists say.
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.description: With his days as a sherpa of the Andes growing short, Americo González Caldua laments the disappearance of magnificent ice sheets he once took for granted.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: ‘Nutella Riots’ in France Show Price of a Sweet Tooth
item.description: When a French supermarket chain announced a promotion on the chocolate-and-hazelnut spread, Black Friday-like scenes ensued all over the country.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Women Outnumber Men in Oxford’s Newest Class. It Only Took 1,000 Years.
item.media:description: A graduation ceremony at Oxford. Though Oxford reached a milestone, it was still catching up with national trends.
item.description: The incoming class in 2017 had 1,070 women and 1,025 men, a bit of catching up in a country lately more worried about lagging male attendance.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: On Turkey’s Border With Syria, Many Are Eager for War
item.media:description: Scores attended the funerals of two victims of a rocket attack in Kilis, Turkey, on Thursday. Many said they supported Turkey’s offensive against Kurdish militants across the border.
item.description: After a rocket attack, townspeople say Turkey’s president should have started his offensive sooner against Kurdish militants.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Amid Protests, Honduran President Is Sworn In for 2nd Term
item.media:description: The police in Tegucigalpa used tear gas on Saturday to disperse people protesting the inauguration of Juan Orlando Hernández.
item.description: The pomp-filled ceremony, coming after weeks of unrest over a widely disputed election, was marred by new clashes between security forces and protesters.
item.dc:creator: JEFF ERNST and ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: A Deadly Blast in Kabul
item.description: A bomb placed inside an ambulance exploded on a busy Kabul street on Saturday, killing at least 95 people and injuring at least 158 others. The explosion comes a week after another attack shook the city.

item.title: Foreign Fighters Back Kurdish Militia in Syria in Fight Against Turkey
item.media:description: An image from a video released on Friday is said to show foreign fighters in the Kurdish People’s Protection Units militia, also known as the Y.P.G., arriving in Afrin, Syria.
item.description: Many Westerners who identify with the promise of a Kurdish state have joined the Y.P.G. militia, battling first the Islamic State and now Turkey.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Fake Country Carved From Catalonia Means to Mock Separatism
item.media:description: As the new Catalan Parliament met this month in Barcelona, many in a crowd outside held banners reading “libertat,” the Catalan word for “freedom.”
item.description: The founders of make-believe Tabàrnia intend for it to send a serious message: That one declaration of independence could set off a cascading series of breakaway nations, to the point of absurdity.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: The U.S. May Back a Vietnam Coal Plant. Russia Is Already Helping.
item.media:description: A farmer tending his fields next to the site of the Long Phu 1 coal-fired power plant in Soc Trang Province, Vietnam.
item.media:credit: Quinn Ryan Mattingly for The New York Times
item.description: A state-run company in Vietnam is seeking support from the Export-Import Bank for a project that could benefit American business but is criticized by environmentalists.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Free Trade Disillusionment and the First Hipsters: The Canada Letter
item.media:description: Peterborough, Ontario, where there has been a steady exodus of large factories.
item.media:credit: Aaron Vincent Elkaim for The New York Times
item.description: This week’s Canada letter looks at the decline in manufacturing and some remarkably clear images from the 19th century gold rushes.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Deaths of Billionaire Toronto Couple Were Homicides, Police Say
item.media:description: A body being removed last month from the home of Barry and Honey Sherman in Toronto. Police are now treating the deaths as a double homicide.
item.description: Toronto authorities have ruled out murder-suicide, but they have no suspects yet in the mysterious killings.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE PORTER

item.title: Saudi Arabia Frees Media Mogul, but His Company’s Fate Remains a Mystery
item.description: MBC’s owner resisted a purchase offer from Saudi Arabia’s crown prince. He was among those seized in what the Saudis called a corruption crackdown.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Davos, Mueller, Syria: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Julian Assange Asks U.K. Court to Drop His Arrest Warrant
item.media:description: Julian Assange speaking at the Ecuadorean Embassy in London last year.
item.description: The WikiLeaks founder suffers from depression, his lawyer said, and fears that if he leaves the Ecuador Embassy in London, he might be extradited.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Grounded and Gutted, Main Afghan Airline Struggles After Taliban Attack
item.media:description: Kam Air employees with the coffins of Ukrainian colleagues who were killed in the weekend attack on the Intercontinental Hotel in Kabul.
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.description: With insurgents threatening road travel, Kam Air has kept Afghanistan moving. But its future looks grim with foreign crew members dead or fleeing.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and FAHIM ABED

item.title: Training Quick and Staffing Unfinished, Army Units Brace for Surging Taliban
item.media:description: Afghan Army soldiers outside Kabul in October. American advisers will help train Afghan forces, including marshaling air support and artillery when they are targeted by the Taliban.
item.description: A brigade of military advisers is being heralded as a key part of President Trump’s strategy to turn the tide in Afghanistan, but its commander has raised internal concerns about the challenges it faces.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS GIBBONS-NEFF
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Center for a New American Security

item.title: Italian Student in Cairo Was Murdered Over His Research, Prosecutor Says
item.media:description: A vigil in Rome on Thursday marking two years since the disappearance of Giulio Regeni, an Italian student who was found dead in the outskirts of Cairo.
item.description: Giulio Regeni was killed because of his academic interest in Egypt’s independent labor unions, Rome’s chief prosecutor said in an open letter.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Exploited and Extorted, 30 Africans Drown While Trying to Return Home From Yemen
item.media:description: African migrants waited to board a boat in the southern port city of Aden, Yemen, before being deported to Somalia in 2016.
item.description: En route to Djibouti, the Ethiopians and Somalis died after a confrontation with traffickers in an overloaded boat.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: BBC, Criticized Over Pay Gap, Cuts Salaries of Some Male Journalists
item.media:description: The BBC presenter Jeremy Vine was one of several male journalists at the British broadcast to take a salary cut.
item.description: The British broadcaster said it was reducing the salaries, after its China editor decided to leave that position to protest unequal pay.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: A Sober Trump Reassures the Davos Elite
item.media:description: President Trump on Friday with the founder and executive chairman of the World Economic Forum, Klaus Schwab.
item.description: In a restrained speech, the president argued that his “America First” policies were consistent with the current global economic system.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Floods Leave Paris Contemplating a Wetter Future
item.media:description: A park on Île de la Cité in Paris on Thursday.
item.description: The Seine River overflowed its banks for the second time in less than two years, raising questions about a potential pattern.
item.dc:creator: ELIAN PELTIER and ELOISE STARK

item.title: Trump: ‘America Is Open for Business’
item.description: Speaking for the first time at the World Economic Forum, President Trump said that the world was witnessing the resurgence of a strong, prosperous United States that is competitive once again.

item.title: China Embraces a Game About a Traveling Frog
item.description: For whatever reason, Travel Frog, an extremely low-key Japanese mobile game, is a hit in China. “You don’t even need to think about anything,” one player explained.
item.dc:creator: KAROLINE KAN and AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: South Korea Hospital Fire Kills at Least 37 People
item.media:description: Officials said they were still investigating the cause of a fire that engulfed Sejong Hospital in Miryang, South Korea, that killed at least 41 people.
item.description: The deadly blaze was the latest in a string of a tragedies that have heightened public concern over the country’s safety standards.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Allies or Terrorists: Who Are the Kurdish Fighters in Syria?
item.media:description: Mourners carry the coffins of civilians and military personnel killed in Afrin, Syria, during the Turkish offensive launched last weekend.
item.description: United States cooperation with the Kurdish group has complicated ties with Turkey, which views them as terrorists.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and BEN HUBBARD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Davos Memo: Trump and Davos: Not Exactly Best Friends, but Not Enemies Either
item.media:description: Mr. Trump arriving in Davos. “The real message is we want great prosperity and we want great peace,” he said.
item.description: Last year, the chieftains at Davos were panicked at the thought of Trump. This year, they welcomed him with somewhat open arms.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and PETER S. GOODMAN

item.title: Davos, Dreamers, Doomsday: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: Victory in Russia Election Assured, Putin Seeks High Turnout
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin meeting with rally car drivers during a campaign stop on Thursday in Kazan, Russia.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: In his bid for another term, the Russian president is seeking the legitimacy of a contested vote without real democracy. It is a hard sell.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: China’s Emissions: More Than U.S. Plus Europe, and Still Rising
item.media:description: The Wujing Coal-Electricity Power Station in Shanghai in 2017. China’s electricity consumption jumped 6.6 percent last year. Wind and solar energy grew quickly, but not nearly enough to meet the extra demand.
item.description: An economic upturn led to rising fossil-fuel emissions after two years of drops, showing the task Beijing faces in fulfilling its climate promises.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER and LISA FRIEDMAN

item.title: In Davos, Trump’s Isolationism May Isolate Him
item.description: Several world leaders highlighted integration and cooperation as vital for the global economy ahead of President Trump’s arrival at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

item.title: The World Bank Is Remaking Itself as a Creature of Wall Street
item.media:description: Jim Yong Kim, president of the World Bank. “One of the most difficult things to do in a large bureaucracy is to change incentives,” he said.
item.media:credit: Andrew Mangum for The New York
item.description: Jim Yong Kim, the World Bank’s president, is trying to revitalize a hidebound institution. But his embrace of Wall Street is controversial.
item.dc:creator: LANDON THOMAS Jr.

item.title: Ivory Coast Arrests Six in Ring That Smuggled Parts of Elephants, Leopards and Pangolins
item.media:description: Ivory Coast’s minister of water and forests, Alain-Richard Donwahi, center, examined seized elephant ivory with other Ivorian officials at the headquarters of the country’s Transnational Organized Crime Unit in Abidjan on Thursday.
item.description: The crackdown follows another major bust of an ivory trafficking network in Gabon
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.category: Eco Activists for Governance and Law Enforcement (Eagle Network)

item.title: U.S. and Pakistan Give Conflicting Accounts of Drone Strike
item.media:description: The site of a United States drone strike in northwestern Pakistan on Wednesday.
item.description: United States officials rejected a claim by Pakistan that the strike had targeted an Afghan refugee camp.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: 10 Monkeys and a Beetle: Inside VW’s Campaign for ‘Clean Diesel’
item.media:description: Testing a Volkswagen Golf in California in September 2015. That month, the carmaker admitted that it had installed illegal software to help its cars evade standards on diesel emissions.
item.description: An experiment that produced false data sheds light on how German automakers financed scientific research to promote their political agenda.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING
item.category: European Research Group on Environment and Health in the Transport Sector

item.title: Doomsday Clock Is Set at 2 Minutes to Midnight, Closest Since 1950s
item.media:description: From left, Sivan Kartha, a senior scientist at the Stockholm Environmental Institute; Lawrence M. Krauss, director of the Arizona State University Origins Project; Robert Rosner, a theoretical physicist at the University of Chicago; and Sharon A. Squassoni, research professor at George Washington University, at a news conference in Washington on Thursday to announce that the Doomsday Clock had been set to two minutes to midnight.
item.description: The “clock,” kept by the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, is a symbolic measurement of scientists’ concerns about disaster.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: A Beginner’s Travel Guide to Haiti, El Salvador and Africa
item.media:description: A view of Fort des Oliviers in southern Haiti.
item.media:credit: Christopher Miller for The New York Times
item.description: With recent reported inflammatory comments, President Trump put the spotlight on places many Americans have never visited. Here are some travel recommendations on a few of those places.
item.dc:creator: JUSTIN SABLICH

item.title: Theresa May Arrives in Davos as U.K.’s Post-‘Brexit’ Slide Continues
item.media:description: Theresa May, Britain’s prime minister, speaking on Thursday. “As we leave the European Union,” she said, “the U.K. will continue to be a global advocate of free trade.”
item.description: Britain’s stature as a global economic power has lessened since it voted to leave the European Union. Mrs. May’s speech at the World Economic Forum, and the reception to it, underscored that reality.
item.dc:creator: PETER S. GOODMAN
